citations.narrative:
There is significant clutter in the field area near the food storage barn and goat enclosure. This area contains excess
items, including old machinery, batteries, fencing materials, tires, chemicals, and piles of wooden pallets. Additionally,
there are various miscellaneous items stacked on top of these piles. Piles of debris like this can harbor insects and vermin
that could injure the animals or cause disease.
Failure to clean the premises can lead to health hazards and contribute to the development of pest breeding and living
areas. Keeping the premises clean is essential to protect the animals from health hazards, minimize breeding and living
areas for pests, and facilitate good husbandry practices. Correct by January 9, 2024.

The facility’s current pest control program is ineffective. The large barns which contain multiple primary enclosures
housing primates had many rodents and rodent droppings present. The rodents were observed inside and on top of the
enclosures. Pests can transmit disease, contaminate food and surfaces, and can harm animals. The facility must
establish and maintain an effective program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests.
Correct by December 29, 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
There is significant clutter in the field area near the food storage barn and goat enclosure. This area contains excess 
items, including old machinery, batteries, fencing materials, tires, chemicals, and piles of wooden pallets. Additionally, 
there are various miscellaneous items stacked on top of these piles. Piles of debris like this can harbor insects and vermin 
that could injure the animals or cause disease. 
 
Failure to clean the premises can lead to health hazards and contribute to the development of pest breeding and living 
areas. Keeping the premises clean is essential to protect the animals from health hazards, minimize breeding and living 
areas for pests, and facilitate good husbandry practices. Correct by January 9, 2024. 
3.131(d) 
   
Sanitation. 
The facility’s current pest control program is ineffective. The large barns which contain multiple primary enclosures 
housing primates had many rodents and rodent droppings present. The rodents were observed inside and on top of the 
enclosures. Pests can transmit disease, contaminate food and surfaces, and can harm animals. The facility must 
establish and maintain an effective program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests. 
Correct by December 29, 2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
